stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on a new paper-airplane ride/launch mechanic for an (unnamed) course with pyramids and multiple biomes, debugging unstable flight physics until it produces a controlled “swoop” path and can reliably land on/near the pyramid. He also shows substantial off-stream progress: paper targets, a Toad NPC that dispenses a star, rubber-band launch animation work (including a Fast64 export quirk), and a major update that the demo is effectively finished with N64-specific rendering/performance fixes (AA toggle, coverage/alpha artifact fix, 60fps areas).
stream_context.significance_reason: He states the demo is essentially done and showcases key N64 fixes/performance improvements; he also completes the paper-airplane feature enough to declare the target mission finished and demonstrates new NPC/mission plumbing (Toad star dispensing) plus an exporter-related animation fix.

findings.summary: Kaze declares the paper-airplane feature “done,” stating it completes the target mission; he identifies a reproducible bug when pressing A on the first frame after firing from a cannon and notes the feature otherwise behaves as intended.
Paper-airplane flight was unstable due to a random stack value being used, causing erratic behavior; once corrected, he could properly observe and tune velocity/pitch interactions.

He converges on a controllable flight model by tying pitch acceleration to face/phase angle pitch (rather than only y-velocity), adding clamping and friction/resistance, and reintroducing small “chaotic” forces to avoid the system stabilizing into a boring path; gravity magnitude ("4") is used as a realism anchor because it matches Mario 64’s typical gravity.

The paper-airplane path is intended as a traversal tool: the plane should ‘swoop’ and ultimately land onto/into the pyramid area; on contact with the pyramid, Kaze wants the motion to stop immediately so the plane acts like a precise elevator/ride to reach the top.

The course is still unnamed (working suggestion: “Handmade Heights”) and is described as having distinct biomes in one map (desert, mountains with Styrofoam, castle area, grasslands), reinforcing a multi-zone stage concept.
He finished programming paper targets off-stream: they can be broken by Mario’s face (animation still needed). He also added an additional cannon to the level to support the mission flow.

A Toad NPC interaction is implemented: after a short talk delay, it correctly dispenses a star and Kaze verifies it doesn’t spawn duplicate stars; he also considers an animation for the moment the star is given and a mechanical/soulless voice style for the NPC text/audio tone.
Kaze states the demo is “all done,” claiming he fixed the remaining N64 bugs; he plans further console testing and likely a video of a full playthrough to validate stability.
On real N64 builds, he recently fixed anti-aliasing option handling; toggling AA off can yield nearly ~50 FPS in a shown scene, and he highlights the HUD readability/quality on N64 as a success case.
He fixed a prior visual artifact (a line through geometry) attributed to a coverage-multiplied-by-alpha behavior; he notes there are still a couple of Z-ordering issues visible in the scene.

Texture flicker/‘offset’ issues are described as a Glide/renderer quirk rather than a true game-side offset bug; he frames mipmapping—not AA—as the real solution for flicker, but notes Fast64 currently supports only two mipmap levels, and adding more would require hand-written display lists, which he considers too disruptive for iteration.
He confirms the project’s stretched 16:9 presentation can visually stretch letters; running true native widescreen in an emulator avoids that distortion.

He prefers giving the airplane a physical basis (even if heavily “fudged”) rather than precomputing or splining a path, because the system must be computed at least once and he wants the motion to feel grounded in simulation.

He argues that the bar for 3D platformers is “incredibly low,” and that a game/hack that simply “doesn’t suck” can become popular; he cites Battle for Bikini Bottom as an example of a game that’s mostly neutral but buoyed by small positives (character interactions).

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly joins while Kaze shows the completed paper-airplane mechanic; Kaze notes the rubber-band slingshot still needs to actually sling Mario (implying remaining feature work after the paper-airplane milestone).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I thought what made you insane when you romhack is the romhacking itself. But no, it’s Twitch chat watching you romhack.
memorable_quotes.context: After repeated chat misunderstandings and requests (e.g., backflips), he reframes the emotional difficulty as audience management rather than technical work.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I’ve always been a hater for people that are like, ‘Oh, I can’t work on my ROM hack because I have school.’ School is like six hours a day. You’re still awake for 10 hours beyond that.
memorable_quotes.context: A blunt statement about time management and personal accountability in hobby dev; useful for exploring his work ethic and expectations.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think the bar for 3D platformers is so incredibly low that making a 3D platformer is easy at this point.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear creative philosophy about why he believes an original platformer (after the hack) is viable and what “good enough” means to him.

key_stories.title: Taming the paper-airplane physics until it becomes a usable traversal tool
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to make a paper airplane feel like it ‘swoops’ realistically while still landing where level design needs it to. The work becomes a balancing act between a physics-inspired model and intentional ‘fudging’ to get a fun, controllable trajectory.
key_stories.challenge: The plane alternates between chaotic instability (spinning/backflips, runaway pitch) and overly stable/boring flight that won’t regain speed or tip correctly to reach the pyramid target.
key_stories.process: He experiments with pitch/velocity coupling, gravity, friction/resistance, clamping pitch limits, and introduces small ‘chaotic’ terms to prevent the system from settling. A key debug moment is discovering a random stack value contaminating behavior. He also considers (and rejects) a purely scripted spline approach in favor of a simulation-based feel.
key_stories.outcome: He reaches a “good base” where the swoop motion looks plausible and can be tuned to land at the pyramid; he frames it as effectively complete for the target mission, with remaining work being numeric tuning and contact/stop behavior on the pyramid.
key_stories.key_quote: I didn’t think that programming a paper plane was going to be this much of a problem.

key_stories.title: Off-stream feature push: paper targets and the target mission get finished
key_stories.summary: Beyond on-stream physics iteration, Kaze reveals that major mission components were built off-stream and then integrated live. This shows a pattern: high-focus implementation off-stream, then on-stream integration/debug and polish.
key_stories.challenge: The mission needed interactive targets, a reliable plane launch/ride, and mission flow support to be demonstrable end-to-end.
key_stories.process: He programs paper targets (breakable with Mario’s face), adds another cannon for the mission route, and then validates the full sequence, including failure behavior when speed is too low. He identifies a cannon bug caused by pressing A on the first frame after launch.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze states the paper airplane is “done,” explicitly saying it completes the target mission, with one known first-frame input bug documented.
key_stories.key_quote: Either way, the Paper Airplane is done. That finishes the target mission.

key_stories.title: Demo reaches ‘done’ status with N64-focused rendering/performance fixes
key_stories.summary: Kaze announces the demo is essentially finished and demonstrates recent N64 improvements that materially affect how the project looks and performs on original hardware. He highlights both visual correctness and framerate as core success criteria.
key_stories.challenge: N64-specific artifacts and performance issues (AA handling, coverage/alpha artifacts, Z ordering) were blocking confidence in the demo build.
key_stories.process: He fixes AA option behavior (including an ‘AA off’ mode that significantly improves framerate), resolves a visible line artifact tied to coverage*alpha behavior, and checks scenes for remaining Z-ordering issues. He emphasizes continued console testing and a possible full playthrough video for validation.
key_stories.outcome: The demo is presented as effectively complete, with remaining tasks framed as verification/polish rather than core feature work.
key_stories.key_quote: The demo is all done, by the way. I fixed all the N64 bugs.

key_stories.title: Fast64 ‘smart animation range’ cuts the first frame of the rubber-band animation
key_stories.summary: While animating a rubber-band slingshot, Kaze hits a toolchain issue where the animation doesn’t start correctly. The resolution reveals a subtle export rule that could impact other animated assets.
key_stories.challenge: The rubber-band motion looks wrong because the first intended animation frame isn’t present after export, making timing/easing appear broken.
key_stories.process: He investigates timing and export behavior and concludes Fast64’s smart animation range is trimming frames until the first keyed frame. By not having a keyframe before frame 1, the initial pose gets cut; adding an earlier keyframe preserves the start pose and restores expected motion.
key_stories.outcome: He gets a smooth rubber-band animation base and decides he can manually sculpt bounce if easing still doesn’t import as desired.
key_stories.key_quote: The first animation frame wasn’t exporting because there’s a smart animation range feature that cuts out all the frames until the first one we have a keyframe on.

open_questions.topic: The ‘demo is all done’ claim vs. remaining verification scope
open_questions.context: Kaze says the demo is finished and N64 bugs are fixed, but also says he hasn’t fully tested the demo on console yet and wants to do a full playthrough video.
questions: When did you decide the demo was ‘done’—what checklist or threshold were you using (content complete, performance, crash-free on hardware)?
What were the last few N64 bugs you fixed that finally made the demo feel shippable, and how did you track/validate them?
After declaring it done, what kinds of problems are you still worried might surface in full console testing (timing, memory, Z issues, controller edge-cases)?

open_questions.topic: N64 rendering pipeline changes: AA toggle, coverage*alpha artifact, and remaining Z-ordering issues
open_questions.context: He demonstrates improved performance with AA off (~50 FPS in a scene) and mentions fixing a line artifact caused by coverage multiplied by alpha, while noting some Z-ordering issues remain.
questions: What specifically was the ‘coverage multiplied by alpha’ issue in your pipeline—what was wrong, and what change fixed it?
How are you deciding when to trade AA quality for framerate in different parts of the demo—do you plan dynamic toggles, per-area settings, or a single global mode?
What are the remaining Z-ordering issues you spotted—are they content-authoring problems, microcode/material settings, or engine-side sorting limitations?

open_questions.topic: Toolchain limitation: Fast64 mipmap levels and the ‘too disruptive’ cost of hand-written display lists
open_questions.context: Kaze says Fast64 only supports two mipmap levels even though N64 can do more, and that doing it by hand would require reinserting custom display list work every export iteration.
questions: How often do mipmap limitations show up as a real art constraint in Return to Yoshi’s Island (specific textures/areas), and what workarounds are you using today?
Have you considered creating a small post-export patcher that automatically reinserts the extra mipmap setup, so you’re not hand-editing display lists every time?
What would need to change in Fast64 (feature-wise) for you to adopt richer mipmapping without slowing down iteration?

open_questions.topic: Design intent for the paper-airplane: simulation-based feel vs. authored path reliability
open_questions.context: Kaze resists using a spline/precomputed path, preferring a simulation ‘with a physical basis’ even while admitting he’s heavily fudging values to hit level design targets like the pyramid landing.
questions: What does ‘feels like a real paper plane’ mean to you in player terms—visual motion, controllability, unpredictability, or all three?
How do you decide what level of chaos is fun versus frustrating, especially when the mechanic is also a traversal requirement?
If you later find the sim creates edge-case failures (speedrun exploits, camera weirdness, missed landings), would you ever switch to a partially-authored path—what would make you compromise?
